thread.title: FTSE 100 hits seven-month low

title: FTSE 100 hits seven-month low
text:
-0.18 
Britain's benchmark index closed at 6,403 - 0.1pc away from official correction territory 
Investors in Britain’s leading companies were left nursing hefty losses as fears intensified over the ailing health of the Chinese economy. 
Britain’s benchmark index closed 122.84 points, or 1.9pc, lower at 6,403.45, hitting its lowest level since January and putting the index 2.5pc below where it finished last year. 
The latest FTSE fall has taken the sell-off, since the FTSE 100 recorded an April high of 7,104, to 9.9pc - 0.1pc away from ‘official’ correction territory of 10pc. 
Rebecca O’Keefe, of Interactive Investor, said “with Chinese growth slowing, commodity prices have fallen to 13-year lows and the knock on effect on commodity producers has been dramatic”. 
Concerns demand from China, the world’s largest metals consumer, will take a hit sent the mining sector to its lowest level in six-years. Commodity stocks became the biggest casualties on the FTSE with Glencore (Xetra: A1JAGV - news ) and Anglo American falling 9.7pc and 4.4pc, respectively. * Commodity markets are in meltdown but Glencore will survive While the FTSE teeters on the brink of correction territory, global equity markets were also a sea of red, as concerns over China dominated investor sentiment. The CAC in Paris slid 1.8pc and the German DAX lost 2.1pc. * Lonmin (LSE: LMI.L - news ) plunges to 27-year low as its financing problems deepen
